You can vet them to a point, I agree. There is no way in which you can 100% guarantee somebody is not lying. However, many of the stories are based upon multiple sources. You will find very few which rely on just a single source unless that source is INCREDIBLY reputable.
For example; it is likely that the Comey story from a couple of days ago (or maybe it was yesterday?) was actually leaked by Comey. The journalists would have known it was Comey speaking to them. Would you really need to vet any more than that? The guy is not exactly a liar.
I would say more sources in the mainstream media are accurate. Companies don't thrive by making up lies (except Fox News, for some very odd reason)

I can promise you, no matter what you think, those people are going to be vetting their sources. Just because you do not want to believe that does not make it true.
-edit-
Huffington Post may be a little bit different due to the way they work. I have never written for them. I know that some of the stories are just put up without any editorial control, but I don't think that happens on the news side of things. Other major websites (New York Times etc.) will put sources through multiple checks.
You are aware that anonymous sources are not actually anonymous? Journalists will know who is giving them the information and would have vetted them to ensure they are as reputable as possible.
